review_title: Very exciting things are happening at Lumen!
pros:
The new name and brand have given us a chance to focus on a singular goal - to make amazing happen. Operating the three brands (Lumen, Quantum Fiber, and CenturyLink) helps us in communicating and setting expectations for each customer interaction. Our products and services are critically important to our customers, especially in a post-covid world. We are raising the bar each day and it is an exciting place to work.

The company has also adjusted to embrace work-from-work and work-from-home options depending on the role and safety of the employees. The new collaboration technology we are using has accelerated improvements in team cohesiveness and building relationships. This allows for more flexibility for employees and helps to achieve a strong work/life balance.
cons:
We have grown through a lot of mergers and acquisitions over the years and that has proven to come with its own challenges. The processes and systems environment has some technical debt that we are working through. There is a clear roadmap and plan, it just takes time.
Advice to Management
We need more creative, passionate, and out-of-the-box thinkers to help us fulfill the Lumen mission.
Helpful
Lumen Response
January 7, 2021 –
Thank you for the 5-star review, and for your thoughtful feedback. We are lucky to have AMAZING people like you on our team
advice_to_mgmt:
We need more creative, passionate, and out-of-the-box thinkers to help us fulfill the Lumen mission.
Helpful
Lumen Response
January 7, 2021 –

review_title: Great company to start your career at
pros:
I was part of the College Connect Sales Academy that runs for 12 weeks before you are put in market. It is designed for recent college graduates. I really found that it gave me an in depth knowledge of a career in sales. 
In terms of the role itself, you get to own your own accounts and have a support team including a Solution Engineer, Customer Success Manager and your Sales Director to support you and help you make sales. It’s nice to have your own book of business and decide how you want to work with each account. The commission structure is also good, as long as your are hitting or exceeding your quota.
cons:
After the big restructure in late 2020 and getting rid of the global team and verticals (I.E. pharma, oil and gas, manufacturing), the company is losing it’s unique spark. I am now in the mid market group and have 45 accounts I manage, with only 3 actually billing and the other ones dark/dim. I feel as though management is setting unrealistic goals of having 5 meetings a week, 2.5 times your quota per week and 10 times your quota per month (this pertains to regional mid market group). There will be months where you do not have any sales at all, however on the other hand, there will be times you hit or exceed your monthly quota. Your success with sales really depends on the accounts you get as well as timing (meaning do the accounts have the budget to implement what solution you are proposing to them, does this align with their monthly, quarterly or yearly goals). You may work extremely smart and hard prospecting in the accounts (both billing and dark/dim) and still get nothing. I also feel that a promotion is also based on luck (meaning how well you are doing with sales in your accounts).
Advice to Management
Please set more realistic expectations and rethink your quota and meeting goals for the week and month. If a person is given dark/dim accounts to grow, the AM’s expectation is hope for the best and expect the worst, meaning if you reach out to those non billing customers, you are lucky if you get a response.
Helpful
Lumen Response
January 19, 2021 –
Thank you for leaving a review. We are happy to see you enjoyed the College Connect Sales Academy and have continued to grow your career in Sales

review_title: They are crooks and should be ashamed
pros: The Medical insurance Bind is the only pro of this disgusting company
cons:
I worked for this company for several years. I can only equate them to the criminal coal mines of our countries past. They steal commissions , underpay their employees half of what market rates should be. They promote employees under qualified for blind loyalty to their scrupulous business practices. In one of the worst economic downturns in our country an employee should not have to worry about feeding their family because of the misaligned accounting practices of their compensation group. It’s appalling at the very least. Hard working sales constantly having to chase after continually changing quotas and underpayed competitive base pays. This company is run by crooks who have no accountability for their actions. Empty promises, lies , allowing accounts to be taken away once built up to a productive level. The unnecessary hardship inflicted on employees produced by this company is disgusting.
Advice to Management
Pray that your reckoning for how you treat your employees would be merciful. That your greed would be met with accountability. Stop treating your employees like slaves and treat them like valued workers. Your employees should not have to worry about shelter and feeding their families because of this companies greed. Clawing back commissions and wrongly without properly fixing the mistakes made on the part of your compensation department. Get reality check upper management is so detached from the reality of what this company needs to really be a powerhouse in this industry . Start with how you treat and compensate your employees based upon their value. Open your eyes because your blind ignorance will ruin this company .

review_title: Run, don't walk from this company
pros: decent base & benefits . expansive network and global presence. As with anywhere there are some really nice people. Work / life balance depending on who you work for.
cons:
Leadership out of touch with reality. Back end systems and processes are broken beyond repair. Employees more concerned with process than taking care of customers. Sales comp plan structure is overly complex and getting complete and accurate accounting is impossible. HR is over bearing and inserts itself into management decisions making it impossible to retain good talent and hanging on to terrible employees. Every answer is NO . "Compliance' is blamed for all things that get messed up, declined or otherwise screwed up. Spent 99% of my time fixing problems instead of doing my job. Complete disregard for common sense, Leadership is completely out of touch. Personally saw serious pay inequities for minority employees and had to bare knuckle fight HR to correct what was obvious discrimination for one employee whilst watching under performers get a pass. Customer implementations were all botched and delayed for internal process errors . The network outages were constant and not taken seriously. Response to outages were slow and nobody cared about the impact to the customer or their business. 
 Single handedly the worst professional experience I have had in anotherwise fantastic 25+ year career in this industry.
Advice to Management
You can change the companies name and branding, but it might as well be putting bark dust over dog poop. Your problems in the back office are still there. Ed Morche and Jeff Storey are clueless . Bring in new leadership and take a good hard look at the back office process . Get HR and Compliance out of the way so that people can do their jobs. Take a good hard look at discrimination in your hiring and compensation - inequities are there you just don't care to address them. Hiring outside consultants to re-architect the sales organization will not fix the underlying issue of a messy back office. Again it's like putting lipstick on a pig.

review_title: Lumen is it's own biggest problem
pros: I did meet some great people (but great people are everywhere, so this isn't really a differentiator). Lots of jobs available both internally and externally. Comprehensive (though non-differentiating) benefit package. Solid severance.
cons:
Odds of this being read by Lumen is sub 10%. Obviously this is based on my experience. Nearly every major known "red flag" for a new employee happened inside 4 weeks of starting employment: expected reporting location changed from a 19 minute drive to a 1:05 minute drive with no choice (pre-pandemic). Primary job role/function agreed upon during interview process and hiring was changed to a completely different repsonsibility/expectation outside the functional area of expertise (think "applied and hired as a plumber, job changed to electrician upon arrival), expected job hours changed significantly from "work when makes sense" to "be here when we expect you too on our schedule," and most importantly, the primary mandate of the group I was part of was not attainable due to organizational structure changes that were already in motion PRIOR to my hire, but were still known changes (this group won't exist in 6 months.

Most employees have been around a very long time - the most commonly expressed reason for this as quoted by them was "keep your head down, always express agreement until the flavor changes again because it always does, and try not to own a program because most don't succeed and you don't want to sink with a ship. It was working for these people!
Advice to Management
I am spending time on this in the hopes that the people I know that are still there can be positively affected, but I am one person with an opinion and Lumen is a huge org that doesn't allow for individuality (not that it's easy!). Empower your teams through involving them in strategic planning. Be transparent with them and let them drive the ship as they are closest to your customers. When people show up to work with a major surprise to their job that impacts them directly, but they had no say it tells them that they either weren't capable of being part of the conversation or couldn't be trusted. I think you can be amazed with what people are capable of! There are great people there that are totally disempowered right now! Set them loose and let them fly!
Helpful (1)
Lumen Response
December 4, 2020 –
Thank you for taking the time to leave a review. We take your feedback seriously and are sorry to see you did not enjoy working at Lumen

review_title: Used to be an awesome career
pros:
It’s a paycheck.
Decent benefits.
Good paid time off.
cons:
Where do I start?
Working for the the phone company was a great thing. Always something to learn, people to help you, managers that were actually coaches. I could see myself staying with the phone company.

Now you get managers that have no clue what you actually do for a job. They give you ratings without being able to tell you exactly what they mean.

This company has lost more knowledge on day to day activities than people still around. They keep pushing out valuable people without training others. Management’s solution is to automate, offshore or contract the work to someone else, to save money. So if you’re involved with any of those three, great place to be.

Continually there are attempts to innovate, but poor development and poor planning leads to failed attempts. This all leads to poor employee attitude and poor customer service.

Before level 3, Centurylink or Qwest mergers there was a great phone company, USWest was an awesome place to be and work. Now they change the name and have great plans for anything having to do with Level 3 or the enterprise side of the company, but again the phone company gets left behind. Careers are a thing of the past!
Advice to Management
Companies are built from the ground up! Value those hard working good employees! Without them, you are also unnecessary! The attitude of the employees is a direct representation of its management!

review_title: Forward thinking company, great values and culture, lots of change
pros: I really resonate with their values, they're the foundation of the company and the person who built it. There's a really strong, family-oriented culture here too, where I've always felt very supported by my peers and mentors. They truly make an effort to improve the employee experience as well. It's also very forward thinking, where there always trying to be ahead of the curve, which provides a lot of cool opportunities to do different roles. They're also good about hiring internally, but also value the perspective of someone new. It's a good balance/range of employees who have been here for 20-30 years and young professionals.
cons:
There's a lot of change at this company, and there usually isn't much time to get used to something before it changes again. The change is very forward thinking and eventually you understand how it'll benefit the company, but often there's a lot going on in the background and you won't find out until a big company announcement is made. It can be competitive sometimes too, but that might depend on where you work/what role you're in. They usually promote having good work like balance, but you can certainly get burnt out just as easily depending on your role.
Helpful
Lumen Response

Thank you for leaving a 5-star review! We are happy to hear you are having an AMAZING experience at Lumen and we agree, Lumen has a strong culture focused on supporting our employees

pros: Feedback is valued. Feedback with proposed solutions is how to set yourself apart. Not all process improvement suggestions are actioned or able to be actioned, but more often than not it can be. Also, not all changes are easy to accomplish, but with proper thought and planning progress can be made. Executive Leadership has the company moving the right direction, and it is up to the middle management and below to identify efficiencies as we know the day-to-day work best. Benefits are good, including the number of days off. Persuasive critical thinkers will make it far in the company. Awesome facilities in Broomfield, including a 24x7 cafe, a cafeteria, a gym with workout classes. Work-life balance is respected in many roles. Honestly, a very good company to work for.
cons:
It is a large corporation and thus there is going to be some level of politics that comes into play the further up in the company. Layoffs do occur, though they generally only affect low performers. The product team is at times misaligned with the reality of how products are delivered and supported.

pros: They pay really well for sales compensation, and you don’t have to work weekends.
cons:
This place is focused more on sales then the actual customer support side of the business. They want you to push sales down the customers throats, and they don’t care what their situation is. So people can be behind on bills, pissed off, fixed income, WHATEVER and you still have to sale. It’s really uncomfortable to push customers off the phone and not really resolve their issues. It’s really stressful to have back to back calls for a 9 hour shift and a majority of those calls you are being yelled at or told how much this company sucks. They are under staffed so expect to be there after closing. They don’t have enough support help so you can ask a question and get a vague af answer. Then not hear anything back for 10 or more mins. But then be yelled at for being on a call for 15 mins. This place is a joke.
Advice to Management
Y’all need to separate the sales and customer service position. People do not want to call for customer service to be hassled to purchase something. Y’all need a better transfer system. Y’all need more support help. Y’all just need to rethink everything and ask your employees how they feel. Or listen to how they feel.

pros: Handling of Covid was strong. If you are in the right role then work/life flexibility and balance is good. Benefits are good. I bet you’ll find new friends within your peers.
cons:
The organization is going through financial chaos and it’s employees who pay the price. Don’t guarantee on job stability or security. I saw employees terminated so departments could meet poorly planned budgets just to have “new” jobs posted shortly after the fiscal year. If your job isn’t terminated then they probably will change it beyond recognition without any conversation. They haven’t had Merit increases for multiple years (4+) so negotiate hard before you join because you probably won’t see more. Don’t expect to have any autonomy or decision making, everything is top down and you’ll probably have multiple levels and verticals of leadership involved with every detail. Decisions move slow and leave limited room for changing the status quo.
Advice to Management
Get better at managing your budgets without falling back on Headcount reductions. Figure out how to distribute decision making (and truly mean it, not just wait until the end for an opportunity to “weigh-in” and then force exhausting rework).

pros: Great company with great benefits. Given the large network, resources and employee base, we are able to provide customers what they want in service and support as technology evolves. It is a very large company with employees and opportunities across the globe including a solid culture, unifying principles and competitive wages. The CEO and other Senior leaders are committed to the company and the customers we serve and it is exciting to be a part of this journey.
cons:
Being a technology company, while exciting and ever changing can be very demanding and sometimes overwhelming as customers are reliant on our business success to lead to theirs. The challenge is always putting the customer first which sometimes leads to a mismatch in work/life balance. Another downside is that it is very difficult to serve the newest innovation/products to customers in established or remote areas due to high cost which unfortunately is misunderstood by most and sometimes leads to negative brand perception.

pros: Smart people, many have been in non-sales roles for decades. Products are mostly top-notch (except the DSL) once finally installed.
cons:
Getting sold products installed is usually a nightmare. In general, it’s a “it’s not my job” culture. Customers constantly unset with installs, long install times. lengthy construction waits and to get billing issues handled. Spent large portions of my day not selling, but handling complaints, tracking down who can fix things internally and putting out other fires. I’ve never had a job before in sales that allowed me so little time to actually sell. The company knows there’s lots of problems, and tries to address them, but it’s a cultural change needed and processes are beyond broken. It will be years before it is a place that functions properly.
Advice to Management
The company knows there’s lots of problems, and tries to address them, but it’s a cultural change needed and processes are beyond broken. It will be years before it is a place that functions properly.

pros: Immediate team members were great.
cons:
Red, blue, orange and green networks. Had to refer to each network by color to keep them straight. Hybrid network designs added a lot of complexity which resulted in improper circuit provisioning. 
Too many systems and complex processes. Bones buried everywhere. Tribal knowledge needed to figure out processes and sometimes that didn’t work. 
Lack of leadership.
No remote working. Needed to be at your desk from 8am to 5pm. 
Benefits were terrible.
Advice to Management
Listen to your front line employees. Fix your complex networks, systems and processes.

cons:
stent hours, mandatory OT, union represented
Cons
First, the job listing is Technical Support Representative, but when you get hired it magically changes to Repair Support Technician, that's incredibly misleading and also kind of unethical to bait and switch people like that.
Advice to Management
Maybe change the job listing to not be so false and misleading. This is not a job in IT, nor does it really involve technical support. Practice what you preach, its one thing to say blah blah blah about company values, and another when other employees and supervisors yell at new people to "get back on the phones". If you run a call center farm, at least be honest with people by accurately listing the job itself.

review_title: Antiquated culture, insane micromanagement and unaccountable leadership
pros: Reasonable benefits. Flexible time-off policy.
cons:
Antiquated culture, zero management accountability.
Advice to Management
You desperately need to update your corporate culture, philosophy, and bring in fresh ideas from outside of your firm. Working for this company is like taking a time machine back to 1986. People have more options for employment than ever, whether it's working remotely for another company or starting their own small venture/enterprise. It's never been easier to leave a bad situation and there's less judgement than ever (particularly during a pandemic) for doing so.

By staying locked in an antiquated mindset and micromanaging everything an employee does and when they do it, all you will do is keep the sad, old lifers who just want their benefits and long ago learned to keep their own opinions and ideas to themselves. You'll lose and chase away the folks who have options and who are unwilling to settle for a depressed / oppressing workplace.
Helpful (3)
Lumen Response

review_title: They miss the mark on the basics.
cons:
mer Sales Representative 
Doesn't Recommend
Negative Outlook
No opinion of CEO
I worked at Lumen full-time for more than a year
Pros
1. Okay pay, but it's not competitive. Especially for what you have to deal with. You can find much better paying jobs that aren't as stressful. 
2. Benefits.
3. GREAT lower level management. Seriously, the supervisors are amazing.
4. Decent culture with teams and coworkers. You make good lifelong friends.
Cons
These are the reasons I left after being a consumer rep for two years. 

1. Too much scrambling around. I moved from customer care to sales and to retention (which was a pay cut of roughly $1500 a month) with hardly any warning or training each time. They actually lost several people because of this specific move. People get promoted and in two months get laid off. Entire centers are shut down with little notice so they can hire vendors overseas to save money. Constantly shifting from product to product - yes I understand split testing is part of marketing but we sold Directv for years, switched to Dish for a month, now we sell Dish, Directv, and AT&T TV. We have whiplash.

2. Horrible customer experience. This can be attributed to a number of things. 
- Slow internet speeds unless in a fiber city. 
- Poor training (I mean supervisors give you different answers to the same questions kind of poor training) which means that customers get WILDLY different experiences every single call. 
- Awful technicians and scheduling. I can't tell you how many customers I lost because the technicians neither showed up to their installations nor called the customers to let them know. Also in Fiber areas they had 2 hour appointment windows but in every other city your installs would sometimes date out up to a month out and make the customer wait between 8-5. Nobody wants to wait 30 days for internet. Same with repairs.
- Systems that don't work. We use 3 main account softwares. One that works great, one that works half the time, and one that doesn't hardly work at all and give the agents incorrect information. Guess which one they require us to use, and which one they are taking away?
- Multiple lawsuits over billing for a reason. They have fixed this mostly with their Price for Life but they still have many customers on older bundles who have no idea their bill is going to increase because they either don't tell them, or a representative misquotes them because of lack of training. 
- Multiple departments dont know what each other do, so customers get transferred several times before being assisted.

3. This is more of an opinion. We all feel that upper level management doesn't care about us or the customer. It's only about money. There is no open door policy. You can talk to your center manager but nobody else will listen to you. Even when you do great work it feels like you're punished and your work is not enough.
Advice to Management
Upper management please take a look at going back to the basics and improving your customer experience. 

Spend the money to upgrade facilities and get customer faster speeds. Nobody can do anything on 3mbps internet. 

Fix your problems with the technicians. Spectrum does one hour appointment windows with several text, email, and phone notifications and even a live tech tracker. AND they do repairs same day. You all do repairs 3-30 days out with NO notifications. 

You're doing good with Price for Life don't ruin it. 

Work out the kinks in your software. Customers shouldn't have to be on the phone for an hour trying to pay a bill because nothing works. This goes along with the transfer process.

Train your agents better. You get very very basic training on the systems, but you learn nothing about sales or customer service or how to handle specific problems. 

Give employees a way to express ourselves without the fear of being a cog in a machine that's easily replaceable.
Helpful (1)
Lumen Response
June 9, 2020 –

advice_to_mgmt:

You're doing good with Price for Life don't ruin it. 

Work out the kinks in your software. Customers shouldn't have to be on the phone for an hour trying to pay a bill because nothing works. This goes along with the transfer process.

CenturyLink is constantly focusing on getting the right things done, including building a sustainable, productive environment. This starts with a collaborative and inclusive culture, with Forbes recently naming CenturyLink as one of America’s Best Employers for Diversity in 2020 as well as receiving a perfect score of 100% on the Human Rights Campaign's list of Best Places to Work for LGBTQ Equality.

CenturyLink also has a transformation and continuous improvement mindset that focuses on both customer and employee experience, offering competitive employee-focused benefits and an opportunity to own your career while striving to create high impact products for customers across all segments. 

I am proud to be part of a company and team that champions a change maker mindset where new, innovation ideas are championed and rewarded.
cons:

pros:
Diverse environment - there's everything from high-end cloud to ancient Solaris and WS2003 boxes. If you ever wanted to learn the breadth of IT, this is a good place. 

Benefits - The Health Care and 401k are decent, the STI is generally reliable. 

Work/Life Balance - The PTO is pretty fair. I was almost never denied a day off.
cons:
Pay - New corporate philosophy is not to give employees raises or COLA. Employees had bonuses and raises taken, then were told they were going to readjust for raises quarterly (they lied, this never happened) then intentionally pushed every manager to flatten their stack to avoid raises. 

But hey, lots of EBITDA!

The management stack on the CTL Business side is downright ghoulish with how disconnected they are from workers. Your frontline manager may or may not care, but it's almost certain that you will very rarely communicate with director, and never communicate with your VP, unless it's them talking to you in a Zoom Meeting. 

This company unequivocably does not care about their employees. They RIFfed hundreds of employees to India, and then had a tone-deaf Hawaiian Shirt Day. They have a tendency to do this - take all the bonuses, but then buy some cupcakes or somesuch. 

They've changed operational paradigms on employees repeatedly, moving Systems Engineers to DevOps without any sort of training or expectation, pushing employees into Project Management without any sort of understanding or training. These employees will generally get hammered by management for not performing a role they weren't hired or trained for. 

Corporate culture is a mess and nepotism and favoritism is rampant. Certain managers are notorious for padding their teams with incompetent employees who were somebody's sexual partner or buddies who rode motorcycles or other complete BS. Pushing back against this nonsense tends to get you branded a malcontent. 

They're also incredibly, stupidly greedy - promoting employees from lower teams at lower pay rates and refusing to readjust them to equivalency with the direct hires until those people leave. 

This culture has so broken the hiring process that many teams have had to hiring in overpaid contractors. The only teams that can fill are entry-level, so anybody entry-level with even a slight spark of talent gets poached up to the middle teams, even though they're unqualified, which drags down the middle teams and the entry-level equally.
Advice to Management
Re-evaluate everyone in the CTL Business stack. (I'd say start from the top, but since the company seems hyper-focused on shareholder returns, so the board's never going to do that...) 

Either develop a current-gen hosting product or learn how to properly sell CAM/MSA. 

Stop compensating for your lack of sales competency and management competency by being cheap and mean to front-line employees.
Helpful (5)
Lumen Response
May 15, 2020 –
Thank you for taking the time to write a review. We have made several organizational and philosophical changes through our integration with Level 3 and our business transformation journey. We work hard to create an inclusive work environment built on the foundation of strong leadership and are sorry to hear your experience with us was not in alignment with our standards and expectations
advice_to_mgmt:
Re-evaluate everyone in the CTL Business stack. (I'd say start from the top, but since the company seems hyper-focused on shareholder returns, so the board's never going to do that...) 

Either develop a current-gen hosting product or learn how to properly sell CAM/MSA. 

Stop compensating for your lack of sales competency and management competency by being cheap and mean to front-line employees.

review_title: CenturyLink is a challenging work environment. There are always a ton of new things to learn. It doesn't ever get old.
pros: Great benefits, terrific management, good camaraderie among coworkers, challenging work, growth mindset, demanding responsibilities.
cons:
Demanding responsibilities, but not all tools work all the time. Numerous legacy dbases and apps to learn. Very cumbersome procedures due to many acquisitions and work models. Low work efficiency - lengthy reward. You need a form to get a form to get a form to get a confirmation of a confirmation...
Advice to Management
Really need to standardize operations across the many legacy companies platforms. Acquisitions helped with growth, more revenue, larger footprint and more customers, but each merger/acquisition added a bunch of procedures, applications, rules, and databases we must work with to get even the most simple things done. I realize it's a considerable investment, but CTL is one more merger/acquisition away from a shutdown due to being over laden with procedures and rules...

review_title: If you don't drink the koolaid or conform, you will never be evaluated on your actual skills
pros: I have learned so much at CTL. So many problems to solve and most of the individual contributors are willing to help out. The benefits are ok. Decent health benefits and decent 401k match. FTO (Flexible Time Off) policy is decent, if you're not guilt tripped or bullied into working more and never taking your days off. Remote work is possible. I got to work remote a lot of the time and in different positions. Peers are usually very smart and hard working. This is a great place to learn about coorporate politics and learn what you don't want in a company.
cons:
ah,... so many to share.... first off, after the merger with Level 3, the culture has reached a point that so many people have been overlooked for promotions or have been bullied into submission. Many people have tried to do the right thing but only to be shunned by leaders that believe they are the end all, be all of the company which has led to a ton of "cost cutting" and overworking of employees. Narcissism and toxic people are at the helm of this sinking ship which in turns creates mid mgmt to be "people pleasers". which in turns allows for bullying and whatever necessary means to pull people inline. If you have ethics and an integrity.... you will be pushed out or you will end up just hearing a story about how someone sucks because that is the narrative they want you to hear. When leaders don't allow for transparency and control the narrative, you should run because one day, the marrative will turn on you. You can only conform for so long before it gets to you.
Advice to Management
The "street" will see thru your cost cutting measures and realize that the growth isn't from true revenue growth but from playing with the number and cutting heads so much that, that the customer suffer in the end. Clean up the culture. The narcissist sales leaders are only out for themselves... not for the entirety of the company.

pros: This is also a good place to get some service provider experience for your resume if needed to get a jump in the market. The company is relatively strong and has enough offices that there are opportunities for everyone. They have a wide range of technology and are starting to invest in some real automation to help with resource constraints. Most roles are setup in a way to offer work life balance. Depending on the role, sometimes does support work from home option.
cons:
Company frequently looks at staffing levels and downsizes in places that may not always make sense. Roles are often very silo'ed and the career path can be limited as the teams are big enough that it could take many years to be promoted and because internal promotions have salary constraints that make it hard to get paid what the role is worth, you may finding yourself having to look outside to actually get paid what your worth as you move up in the company.
Advice to Management
Think there is a need to figure out how to keep people there long term as there has been a lot of knowledge/people lost over the last few years including some good top performers. Management also needs to start to focus on where their people spend their time to truly drive some inefficiencies in delivering their services. Too often business decisions around people are made based on assumptions of tools and systems being delivered that never happen but still impact the overall staffing models. Need to ensure you are holding those committing to those deliverable systems are being monitored and held accountable to deliver said results.

review_title: Big Company, with those burdens. Lots of opportunities too.
pros:
CDN is VERY interesting, exciting. You'll live on the Internet with that kind of work. Cutting edge technology and tools. Big world-wide impact.
Management pays a lot of attention to communication and fairness.
The "Tech Connect" program for bringing on junior developers has been very very effective.
I sense a company that will not put up with any kind of discrimination or harassment.
Benefits are good.
The FTO policy is imply wonderful and helps my life a lot.
It's easy to achieve a good work/life balance.
I have the best manager that I've had in thirty years.
cons:
The merger of multiple companies over the last ten years has left the corporate IT structure in shambles. Even the simplest thing like getting your paystub can be arduous. There is a recent uptick is supplying us with really good equipment.
Management was very reluctant to fire or reassign an incompetent developers.
The company is having a very hard time hiring new developers, especially senior developers.
Centurylink does not look hip or glamorous to interviewees.
Pay in only average.
Stock price has been on slow decline.
Inadequate attention to the value of purchased tools. Big corporate mentality says: "Pay Oracle lots and lots, but don't buy us a cheap alarm tool".
Advice to Management
Loosen up: buy the software guys some tools. Get over that knee-jerk "purchase denied" reaction.
Make the office nicer. It's really really quite corporate drab. (I did notice that IT has very nice spaces, but we don't)
Helpful (1)

pros: There are still some good people left there and you can be a rock star if you understand the telecom business but, don’t look for advancement opportunities because those are few and far between and are only available to former Level 3 employees. Work life balance is good but not good enough to offset the fear and risk of being randomly laid off.
cons:
CenturyLink was a good company until it merged with Level 3. Level 3 leadership is in control and is in way over their heads. Many of the Level 3 leaders are inexperienced and don’t truly understand the business (especially regulated local markets) or how to lead. Level 3 has jettisoned all of the former CenturyLink tools and processes and put their own inferior tools and processes in place setting the company backwards 15 years and catapulting the company towards bankruptcy. Revenues are declining so the company cuts costs by laying off former Qwest/CenturyLink employees in order to meet earnings goals. Layoffs are continuous and secretive. Entire groups are suddenly gone. I chose to leave before I got laid off. 

CenturyLink has no realistic plan to grow revenues. They are in a declining revenue industry. The only way they can survive financially and stave off bankruptcy is to continue to lay off employees to manage earnings and hope that someone buys them before they have to file bankruptcy again. (Level 3 has filed bankruptcy twice previously.)

Leadership lies to employees regularly. For example, they are closing the office in New Century, KS in March 2020. In August 2019, they said they would not be laying off employees and that everyone could work from home if their VP approved. Apparently, a number of VPs don’t like work from home so 300 of the 800 employees in that office are getting laid off. 

Based on the recent employee survey, 2/3rds of employees would not recommend that their friends work for CenturyLink.
Advice to Management
Truly embrace and follow the One Company, One Culture training and you just might succeed. Be honest with employees about layoffs because we can see right through you anyway.
Helpful (12)
Lumen Response
May 19, 2020 –
CenturyLink has a history of growth through acquisitions. As the needs of the business change; we must evaluate our workforce and transform accordingly, to ensure we are able to meet customer demands and remain an industry leader. Unfortunately, at times that means lay-offs and/or reorganizations are needed to drive our transformation. Those decisions are difficult and are not something we take lightly. We are sorry to hear you did not enjoy working here. We have taken extensive and innovative measures to create a combined company culture, reflective of who we are, and who we want to be
advice_to_mgmt: Truly embrace and follow the One Company, One Culture training and you just might succeed. Be honest with employees about layoffs because we can see right through you anyway.

review_title: This company has really gone down hill
pros: Pay is competitive for now but they took away regular raises, and bonus percents are all over the map.
cons:
This company used to be a great place to work, while it was Qwest, and then it got better with the merger with Centurylink. But since the Level 3 merger the company has gone in a very negative direction. The culture is cutthroat, leaders are condescending and autocratic, executives are evil gods that drive a tremendous amount of inefficiency and much wasted time throughout the company. They do this in the name of "data driven" but really all the analytics are political story telling to protect the VP and Director level. The culture that came from Level 3 and has swallowed up CTL is disturbingly negative.
Advice to Management
Ask the leaders of the company to actually adopt the One Company One Culture philosophy. The people at manager and below positions want it badly, and they are frustrated that nobody in a leadership position (Director and above) actually cares about it. Stop treating your employees like they work in a sweat shop. Tell the execs to stop wasting everyone's time on their political asks. Stop gutting the company and pretending that none of it is happening. Spotlight awards are great but they fly in the face of what actually happens there. Employees notice the contradiction between what the award says, and how they are treated. Start treating people with more respect. And maybe take a moment to check out how bad your culture ratings and employee NPS scores have become.

review_title: Not a Sales Centric Organization. Strongly Consider Other Employment Options
cons:
der Other Employment Options"
1.0
★★★★★
Current Employee - Account Manager 
Doesn't Recommend
Negative Outlook
Disapproves of CEO
I have been working at Lumen full-time for more than 3 years
Pros
Great team culture from what I've seen.
Cons
Where to start. There has been a lot of changes within the Sales organization. Layoffs, team adjustments, customer alignment, etc. The overall sales culture is horrible, along with the overall company culture. You can sense the horrible culture is rubbing off on your peers. Especially when it comes to needing help within the ecosystem. It has started to feel like people come in to just punch their time-card and leave for the day. Sales compensation is horrible and hard to understand. You'll consistently find yourself fighting month-after-month to get compensated correctly. If you're promoted while in your role, your pay raise may seem nice. However, your raise will be much less than it would be if you were a new hire off of the streets. Many tools and processes make your day-to-day hard. Service delivery is a huge part of the customer happiness. This is an area that doesn't help your case with keeping the customer happy. Consistent changes to processes and solutions. Telecom is also a dinosaur of an industry, so it makes it hard to compete with the competitors.
Helpful
Lumen Response
May 19, 2020 –
We appreciate your feedback and take your comments seriously. We value all our employees and actively strive to create a positive culture where employees want to come to work every day. Our Compensation team regularly conducts market reviews to ensure CenturyLink pay is market competitive, and even offers accelerated commission programs for our sales roles. We are continuously evolving our sales compensation systems and processes to simplify the employee experience for our sales teams. As a current employee, if you would like to discuss this situation further, please email us at CTLHRActionTeam@centurylink.co

pros: Jeff Storey is great as CEO. Seems to really care.
cons:
I wish I had better defenses to bad psychological activities. Watch out for widespread narcissism. Gaslighting and the supply / flying monkeys. Especially from the Broomfield guys. Well, I only saw it from that office. Mental toughness training is essential, and if you're working for a gaslighter, get out of there. Don't put yourself through it. If you're stuck, a grey rock strategy might be best. Social psychology understanding is a must. I liken my experiences to the Robbers Cave Experiment. Just human nature at work, and unskilled or inattentive management failing to solve bad dynamics, or worse, encouraging these things. Get rid of people if they're not needed, or if needed, help build an environment conducive to success. Help build your people if they're truly needed or cut them loose. Training was not offered. Conflict resolution? Nothing.
Advice to Management
Mandatory skip-level reviews with feedback going to the executive level for adequate oversight. Independent exit interviews offered for EVERY one who leaves. My senior director conducted mine to cover his backside. Not independent. Not enough oversight when I was there. The nature of the job was to use best guesses at solving complex problems with little time to determine optimal solutions, and that's where the gaslighting from others came in. Little respect among team members. That reflects poorly on management skill. Fewer charismatic middle managers. Don't care about their fancy possessions or exotic vacation excursions. Focus should be on customer successes, not social status. Good luck.

pros: Some of the benefits are decent like earning rewards for doing healthy activities.
cons:
I was grossly underpaid for the 5 years I was there... by about 10k compared to other coworkers who did the same job or less. They kept promising a cost of living increase but it was just to string me along. So I missed out on over $50k since I had started. That doesn't include the bonuses that were associated with my salary.... so over 50k. Compared to other corporations the salary would be about 20k a year more than this... So if you want to make money, this is not the place to be. run, and run fast in the other direction. 
Always laying people off.
Medical insurance leaves a lot to be desired and its expensive.
Advice to Management
Pay a living wage to your employees or you will lose them. I was not part of your layoffs that happens each year, I found a new job, had you paid me a living wage I would have stayed. For a multi-million dollar company, there is no excuse for not paying me when I knew not only my job but other people's job in the department and was able to back them up if need be. 
Also, it's a boys club, some of the VPs won't say hi to you or acknowledge you if they see you in the elevator or int the halls. I don't even think they knew where our department was. 
Treat your employees with some respect.

review_title: broken internal systems, dishonest pay/commission, and old school sleazy telecom culture
pros: Vast resources. One of the largest networks in the world
cons:
You will fend for yourself from day 1 trying to navigate the myriad of broken internal systems. Everyone who is supposed to be a support position to sales is actually a gatekeeper to the information/resources you actually need. Simple Quotes can take up to a month to complete. 

The commission structure is purposely confusing and after months of borderline harassment on my part to find out how it works I was informed that I could only make a fraction of what I they initially said. If you do get recruited make sure they give you the compensation/commission info in detail up front so you don’t get screwed like I did.
Advice to Management
Fix the comp plan. You shouldn’t disincentivize success by massively capping first year comp. Get rid of useless gatekeepers who slow down the sales process. If you are actually trying to be a tech company and not a telco stop hiring Telco people to be managers and recruit from SAAS and Managed Services companies.

review_title: Does everything possible to make it difficult to make sales, which is basically all they care about
pros: The base pay is great. Hour and time off are great as well.
cons:
Keep adding extra responsibilities to agents, without adjusting sales goals. Sales goals are weighted on percentage of calls that you take, yet no consideration is given if you have a lot of calls that you need to transfer. Constantly having to transfer calls because their system doesn't know how to route calls properly. Way more dropped calls than other call centers that I've worked at. Way more system issues than they should have, because they are using outdated systems. Adding additional fees for new customers, yet expecting agents to still maintain sales quotas.
Advice to Management
Upgrade systems, especially the outdated phone software. Allow care agents to process move orders instead of having to transfer those. Fix the constant misdirect issues. Stop creating a culture where other reps cancel your orders and submit new ones just so they can keep from losing their jobs. Take orders which complete the following month due to circumstances beyond the agents control into consideration when taking disciplinary action. Upgrade the customer network so that customers who are calling in looking for faster speeds actually have those speeds available. If you're going to have agents push Fiber Gigabit, then actually offer it in more than select areas, and allow free modem and tech installs to existing customers so that agents can actually sell to those customers., rather than having them go to a competitor., or losing the sale to a Retention agent who is empowered to give those to customers. Allow agents to match online pricing to current customers if they ask, rather than, again, losing those customers to a competitor, or losing the upgrade sale to a Retention agent. Fix the Prism billing system. Question: Why the focus on DirecTV, while the website offers streaming promotions??

pros:
Great work / life balance and flexibility, FTO, opportunities to get in front of senior executives and present projects etc., ability to shine with objective metrics that no one can take away from you or be subjective about. I generally see management reward high performers, not sure average or low performers are aggressively rooted out in all departments. Generally good to great people to work with that will happily explain anything to you when asked. Compensation seems good but not excessively great. 

New management is definitely making inroads to change the legacy CTL mindset of "We've always done it that way." More questions are being asked, more financials are being scrutinized as to whether certain endeavors are driving EBITDA and financial metrics. Many have been negative towards this change, but I think it healthy and necessary.
cons:
Highly political corporate america environment cannot be avoided where one's reputation can be tarnished if the right bug is put in the right executive's ear. 

Human Resources seems to think they are the decision makers as to hiring decisions, promotions and comp changes. There is usually little to no documented process as to how go about these things, but then the goal line will move 5-10 times as to the next form to be filled out or another approval to get that speaks to a non-existent process or procedure. Arbitrary at best. HR needs to focus on basic execution of their scope, such as onboarding new employees (a computer for the new employee on their first day consistently would be a great start), payroll etc. that seems to go awry far too often.
Advice to Management
Need to accelerate the product rationalization as we are scattered with our focus at times and need to get more resources and focus on the growth areas. 

Human Resources must understand they are to provide framework to work within and provide guidance and advice, but they are NOT an approver nor are they running the business units. Help us and guide us, but HR is not a decision maker or a step in the approval processes. The EVP of HR needs to go as I think much of this comes from the top based on the various decisions that have to go to the EVP level.

pros: I get paid well and my job is never boring. I like the work because it's challenging and my coworkers are great.
cons:
The company culture has taken a nose dive since the Level 3 acquisition. Things are wildly unstable with layoffs secretly occurring every few months. Constant re-orgs make it difficult to get anything done because you have a new manager or even a whole new team every few months as well. Leadership provides little to no direction on what our strategy is, so you don't know whether your work product will even be used in the long run. Leadership is deliberately vague as to what is happening behind the scenes and why, which leads to a lot of distrust. Employees live in fear of being laid off on any given Friday, which was apparently always the case with Level 3, so much so that they called them "Black Fridays." Steer clear if you like a stable work environment.
Advice to Management
Talk to the people "in the trenches" rather than your immediate subordinate. You're too high up the chain to see what's actually happening on a day to day basis. If you're a VP, talk to your director's managers. If you're a director, talk to your managers' direct reports. If you're a manager, talk you your supervisors' direct reports. We need a skip-level meeting every 3 months. The people actually doing the work know what the reality is, and they are the ones who know what needs to be done, not you. Stop being so secretive all the time. We don't trust you anymore because everything is a surprise that comes out of nowhere. You lay hundreds of people off on a regular basis and are too cowardly to even mention it and explain why and what the process was for determining who was picked. If we don't know why, then we can't adjust our own situations and behavior to prevent it from happening to us. To the remaining employees it's demoralizing and impacts our work because we no longer feel any loyalty to the company, nor do we feel like our work even matters because we might be gone next week anyway.

review_title: Decent compensation, but horrible job security
pros: I was offered a compensation package very competitive for the position I took. Farmers market every Thursday and metro stop directly near the Ballston location. Pretty decent office space except that is a little old and outdated.
cons:
I felt like I started a job in a very unstable department with many coworkers who had a hostile work environment before I showed up. I was the first hire by the new department manager who had only began to run Publications about 5 months before I joined the team to replace an employee who made it out the department alive to another department directly supporting EIS. Because of the way many employees in this particular department had been mistreated in the past I think it left them very jaded and pitted against anyone/anything new. Most of the people here have been there for 5+years and never promoted or grew within the company/department
 Unfortunately, that is not a good thing and it told me plenty about the company in general. I even had numerous Proposal Mgrs request me as their support bc my coworkers who had been there forever didn't want to really work. Unfortunately, the merger happened and the coworkers knew layoffs were coming and in an effort to preserve their own jobs seemed to team up against me and bad talk me to our manager who was on short term disability for months right before yearly reviews. My review from my manager came back glowing as far as my work was concerned, but marked unfairly low for interpersonal skills for which when I asked for examples she could not provide anything. Just goes to show you... it doesn't matter if you do good work...it matters who your buddy buddy with and whose butt you kiss to keep your job. Also, parking g at this location was a RIP OFF!
Advice to Management
Need better management and standards for running a company. Need to start looking at those individuals who seem to just sit in positions for years without providing any substantial contributions to the company goals.

pros:
With the integration of Level3, CenturyLink is now a truly global provider of network services. Solid technical expertise and working hard to get the assets, tools, systems, and processes aligned. Great people to work with!

Great work/life balance, and benefits on par with most global enterprise companies.
cons:
Lots of change happening, as with all mergers/acquisitions, but this one seems particularly challenging. Both companies still have incomplete previous acquisition activities and thus they continue to struggle with integrating. 

Compensation is a very real struggle in this company, let alone the telecom industry. A lot of highly skilled people have left this company due to below market compensation, and it seems like there are always issues with correctly paying the employees. The review/correction process seems to take forever, and the employee has a very limited time to identify and request a correction while the company has unlimited time to go pull back compensation as it deems fit.

review_title: Company attempts to financially fix itself by putting the burden on employees
pros: Flexibility, supervisors are decent. Right before I left they changed the bidding schedule rank to include performance instead of just seniority, which is a move in the right direction since the company hasn't hired anyone for technical support in 2.5 years.
cons:
Very low pay when compared with the same job with other companies like Spectrum, even after the 3% increase they gave because they saw we were underpaid (this was replaced by the 3% you would expect when you get a stellar year review). The company has steadily declined over the past two years with morale and opportunity. No one gets promoted to tier 2 anymore, so no possibility of a pay bump there. They also promise promotions or opportunities coming up and then say nothing for two years. The company used to give an annual Christmas bonus but suddenly two years ago, they stopped and didn't tell anyone until a few days before Christmas. They also cancelled any kind of merit raise, citing cash flow issues (this was right after the merger with Level 3 where humungous signing bonuses were given to execs). After backlash and hundreds of employees leaving the department, they did end up giving the 3% but not until May or June that year. This year the company announced they want a pay for performance culture but didn't even give a 3% raise to top performers in the department. We also got an email from the CEO essentially saying we needed to tighten our belts because the company was paying off debt and couldnt afford to pay us what we deserve. Employees in technical support are also dealing with very irate customers all day because the company doesn't put enough money into preventative maintenance of the network. It's then doubled up because the company also doesn't have enough techs working every day, meaning customers generally wait an average of 4-10 days before anyone comes out to repair (and that's if they show up and are on time). Insurance coverage also declined but the cost increased. I went the doctor for cold symptoms that wouldn't go away for a week and owed $80, which is $5 less than my uninsured relative pays for the same. My specialist used to cost me $65-70 out of pocket and this past year went up to $130. Combining the stress of the job, the low morale, low pay, crappy insurance, and no light at the end of the tunnel makes a perfect mix for employees to hightail it out of there.
Advice to Management
You say you want to pay for performance, so do it. Value employees not just with a cheesy kudos system but with decent pay and better benefits.
Helpful (4
advice_to_mgmt: You say you want to pay for performance, so do it. Value employees not just with a cheesy kudos system but with decent pay and better benefits.

pros: The St. Louis development center's atmosphere is as laid-back as they come. Standard attire include t-shirts and shorts. Depending on the team they are very open to flex scheduling, working from home and overall work/life balance. Perks: 1) Free lunch on Tuesdays & Thursdays, but the catering company they employ is terrible. 2) Free Panera bagel Wednesdays. 3) A gaming room with a 100+" TV, darts, air hockey and foosball.
cons:
Benefits are lousy, pay is mediocre. They think the office perks are worth far more than they are.
CenturyLink is a network company trying to extract every last drop of value left in the shriveled remains of what used to be a viable cloud and managed IT services organization left over from previous acquisitions. Going forward, the company seems uncertain how to utilize these teams, who work in the STL dev center. Necessary investments in projects, people or hardware are promised but haven't happened for years.
Advice to Management

review_title: No career here-- unless you are upper management
pros: Great affordable benefits, work with good team members, and usually even your supervisors will do what they can to help you succeed. A good start to get experience. PTO, sick days allow for amazing ability to have a nice work life balance, and there are health programs to help you stay healthy that the company pays for and *pays you* for if you participate.
cons:
In the big picture, this company is in decline. They are downsizing and going over 'metrics' cutting or moving departments- putting poorly trained people in the place of more experienced reps to further cut costs. - Click to chat jobs are being outsourced to other companies in other countries. Also customer care, and retention. -These call centers to do not reflect CTL values. (Not to mention not having enough techs in many areas, so they are using contractors in areas of the country- some are better than CTL techs, some are not.)
I was part of the a support team that helped fix all the broken orders, we were elites in our field. -- Then corporate decided that they were going to move that department to Monroe LA, and everyone in these departments in 2 call centers lost their jobs- but weren't offered anything but a demotion so no *unemployment* would need to be payed. So they moved us to customer care-- Pays were cut, moral was low, the career path and stability was removed for all of us.--- You will never have a career here--- This company now only offers jobs, and you will fill that job. There is no 'department' to aspire to get to, or a real career. Only real jobs that have stability and a career path are in Monroe, LA if you are going to do call center work.
Advice to Management
Create a good company in the United states. Bring back outsourced jobs besides the 24 hour tech support. The vendor companies don't care about CTL customers, because they just are looking for a sale and to be paid by CTL. Change this- also move away from needing government grants and assistance. STOP expanding and focus on building a better infrastructure. Don't move a department unless you actually know what they are doing beyond a metrics report.

pros: Co workers were amazing, benefits were cool(average, I guess)
cons:
Layoffs. It's something that happens at most companies, but it got to a point where I never knew if I'd have a job in the next 6 months or not. Perhaps I just came in at a bad time.

Less employee focused than it used to be. The CEO has a "take it or leave it" attitude, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. He just seems like he cares more about business than employees, like he doesn't have a heart sometimes. I heard he took away some perks to save money.. small perks, but still. Again, I "heard" that. It could just be rumor

Business over employee attitude seemed to be very prevalent in my management chain as well. I had good managers, but we reorg'd so many times that I eventually started getting some duds. VP and management making promises for our team that are super unrealistic to keep and expecting us to work ridiculous hours everyday, every weekend... for no reason. I again, would like to emphasize that this was my personal experience, but I think it's a bad sign that my management and my CEO seemed to have similar attitudes. There is great management at CenturyLink, but since of my personal experience was just awful. 

Excessive reorg makes it unnecessarily more difficult to move up, because it's like you have to start all over with each new manager/VP to prove that you do good work and be in good standing with them. 

My initial experience was much better and I would have given a higher reading in the past. But my last experience us the most recent and left a lasting impression on me.
Advice to Management
Delivering amazing quality work is one of the most important things. If you find yourself forcing your employees in a long-term "crunch time" mode, then that's not a promise you need to make to business/ customers. Employee burnout is the most dangerous thing. Treat your employees with respect.

cons:
Biggest Con THEY DO NOT PAY YOU YOUR COMMISSIONS. They come up with all kinds of excuses that they weren't able to calculate it correctly, do to their system or . . . They are behind 6 months in paying them out. Also started out with no cap on commissions and once people started to make decent sales they capped your commission. So if you sold over a certain amount you don't get paid it, all the while the company is making that money month after month from the customer. They are very unethical in most of their practices and HR is no where to be found, there's an ethics hot line to call but goes on deaf ears. People have had money stolen out of their purses and NO ONE does anything about it. The building is full of rats and cockroaches, just over all really dirty and VERY out dated. And seriously I have never worked for a large corporation that didn't provide free coffee, seriously. This is a call center gig it's not sales your tied down to the phone, they want you to sell anything you can even if your able to provide the customer with a lower monthly bill it's discourage to never do that. A lot of customers are bundled wrong just so the sales person can get a larger sale. I'd say at least 2 people a week quit or they get fired cause they didn't make quota for the month. They have sales training on a regular basis just to back fill all that leave. Most of friends with management so if you apply to another department don't plan on getting it unless you know the manager. 
 CenturyLink is the most unethical place I have ever worked. Don't do it . . .

Get it together. Treat you employees right. Pay them! Jeff Story is getting paid and he's not being capped.

review_title: This is Level 3, Centurylink in name only. And that's not a positive.
pros: Benefits, WFH, many great and knowledgeable co-workers, breadth of products and services
cons:
A novel could be written about Centurylink post-Level 3 acquisition, and it's extremely important to delineate between Centurylink pre and post-merger. While Centurylink prior to acquiring Level 3 certainly had it's fair share of issues, post-acquisition is an entirely new ballgame and it's not pretty. Former Centurylink Executive leadership has been replaced by L3 execs, processes, and procedures. The actual entire culture has changed. You actually really have to admire how this was all done. 


-Have your debt-laden company acquired by another. 
-Advertise a plan of succession of the acquiring company's leadership. -Proceed to rapidly accelerate that plan, remove nearly all remnants of the acquiring company's leadership in addition to slashing said company's workforce across the board, replace with acquired company's leadership, and VOILA! Mission accomplished. You now get to continue operating as the same company you were before, but now with the added benefit of a much higher brand awareness with the Centurylink name. One doesn't need to look very far to see the results of this. 25 year stock low, slashed dividends, increasing investor frustration and skepticism. 

As others have noted and is evident by looking at Wall Street, this is a company in trouble. Catastrophic failures are occurring in every facet of daily operations. 

-An aloof, arrogant, and tone-deaf Executive Management team that is unaware or unwilling to understand critical issues to the business.

- A middle management layer that has neither the power or the appetite to drive critical change and improvements to the business model and associated processes. Protect your gig at all costs.

- A shocking lack of communication between key departments of the company that are critical to operations and implementation. 

-Continual customer-impacting "modifications", changes, and discontinuations of previous processes and systems, with little to no advance notice, training, or explanation. As a result, employees are left to pick up the pieces and institute damage control after the fact.

-A work environment that has become vindictive, unaccountable, and negative. "One Company, One Culture"....the facade isn't working, guys.

The common thread among all these points is zero accountability for failures in process, strategy, or implementation. "Not my job", "that's a function of____", "we'll need to get XYZ approval for this, "XYZ: that's not something I can do". This is a common daily refrain at the company now. 

As best as anyone can tell, leadership "strategy" now consists of automation, total austerity at the expense of near and long term success, and slash and burn (but only on the Centurylink side, you see). 

Salespeople: 

-Do you like doing being successful at your job (finding/selling/managing business) only to spend 80% of your time on process, administration, implementation, and other assorted roadblocks? 

-If your work somehow makes it through the process gauntlet, do you enjoy navigating multiple, disconnected, archaic systems just to try and track down your pay, only to often find errors in reporting and finance? 

-Do you like being held to account for your quota, while simultaneously having your performance negatively impacted daily due to incompetence and broken processes and systems, only to see leadership of said processes and systems still remain in place even after years of repeated failures, unfulfilled promises and lack of quantifiable improvements?

If so, this is the place for you! If not, stay far away from this place.
Advice to Management
Plenty has already been said about management-this is a group that is clearly in over their heads. No amount of finger pointing, deflection, and blame-shifting about "legacy products/systems" (ie Centurylink) can distract from the fact that you own it, you run it, and the results have been clear. Wall Street doesn't lie and neither do your employees.

Hopefully the board of directors can realize their errors in this process and turn the ship around, but I wouldn't hold my breath.

review_title: Company Gone Off the Rails. Unsalvageable with Current Executives
pros: Working from home for some groups.
cons:
After working nearly 6 years for Centurylink I can say it is in steep decline. 
-Each process is a comedy of errors, extremely contradictory, doesn't work, is poorly executed, has no training included when rolled out, and not even a semblance of accountability when things go wrong.

-The CEO and the VP's of the sales organization do not know what they are doing and are not showing any interest in improving the motivation, energy, and roadblocks to sales success. There is an extreme air of arrogance that taints them, and it shows with the stock reaching the lowest level in 25 years and most of the top sales talent has fled the company!

-Many critically important systems are continually made worse by some random department that is trying to justify their job. They try to replace something that is working perfectly fine. If it's not broke, don't fix it!

-Compensation is a complete and utter disaster. As a high performing sales rep each year I deserve to get paid what i'm worth. The current CEO and leadership does not believe in compensating you a fair salary or commission, thus it's a disaster. The compensation plan has taken a major and game changing turn for the worse in 2019, but in 2018 it was far worse than previous years as well.
**Additionally** There is constant and big mistakes made on commissions where they do not pay you for the sale you made because the bad sales reporting systems do not pick up the sale, thus causing you to wait months longer to get paid what you earned and having to waste a lot of time and energy trying to correct the problem, since they will not proactively do it for you!

-Note of extreme caution to any talented seller thinking about joining the company: I have far exceeded my quota each year I've been with Centurylink and they have not given me a salary raise in over two years and the CEO Jeff Storey announced himself that he doesn't believe in merit raises or even bonuses! how insulting is that?

-Customer service is beyond horrendous--The customers do in fact have a right to complain, and it's far worse than even they think. I have constantly witnesses extremely incompetent service by project coordinators, customer service, billing departments, and other sales teams that dramatically undercut any claims this company has of excellence or values. Internal sales employees can't even get straight answers from order entry and install teams. It's a complete joke and it's baffling how this company is even in operation at this point.(seriously)

-Management, whether intentionally or not, engages in gaslighting. There is constant twists and distortions in reality. We are told one thing and then within an hour the same thing is refuted or proven to be untrue by another manager or department, and are threatened if you don't follow a debunked policy or rule.

-There is definite and noticeable change in energy in the last year that is pessimistic, negative, and de-motivational for the sales organization. Everyone knows it, but not one leader anywhere is doing anything to address it. Total abdication of leadership and responsibility. It's almost as if they're intentionally trying to get people to resign en-masse.
Advice to Management
The CEO, CFO, and most of the Level 3 sales VP's must resign. You are part of problem, and you must realize the majority of people at Centurylink do not like you and do not approve of you or the job you're doing. You can't destroy the compensation plan, install huge roadblocks to selling, ruin processes and expect self-respecting and successful sellers to want to continue to sell your product, as it becomes a liability eventually to even do so

pros: Honestly the job itself was a lot of fun, working with small businesses to improve their internet speeds, upgrade their accounts, fix any problems they had with service, etc. The other guys on my team were great & I made some good friends.
cons:
There were several. First off, our floor was extremely unsanitary. They didn't empty our trash cans except maybe every other week, forcing us to literally work in and around piles of garbage 90% of the time, it gave the whole floor a nasty smell. There was mold on the ceiling tiles that after I reported it to my boss and HR nothing was done to replace them. As of the day that I left the toilets had been busted on our floor for 2 weeks straight, leaving a disgusting sewage smell in the hallway leading to our cubicles. They simply weren't willing to invest any money into our floor or department. On top of those issues getting worse and worse, they weren't paying people the commission checks they deserved. Retention hadn't been paid out for 2018, let alone 2019. SOV checks were 3 months behind and generally much smaller than they were supposed to be. They treated outbound CRIS like absolute garbage, and it smelled like it too.
Advice to Management
You guys need to get yourselves together. Either invest in making the floor a safe space to work in OR make this role a work-from-home role. I could make calls from home just as easy as I could from your smelly, disgusting call center. Actually consider sanitary complaints that employees make instead of just smirking and saying "that's how it is" and prancing away.

review_title: Dinosaur failing to adapt, exacerbating internal failings
pros:
Benefits are pretty good, but not Silicon Valley level
C-Suite (mostly from Level 3 merger) are impressive, have strong vision for the company, and have acknowledged internal dissonance
cons:
(I know this is a frankly brutal review and I want to make it clear I'm not an outlier, bitter about pay or performance reviews. I'm in sales and was one of the top performers in my region last year.)
-Level 3 Acquisition is still far from finished, 18 months in (despite OpEx savings, internal processes are extremely fragmented and while C-Levels acknowledge it and claim they're improving, there is no end in sight)
-Stock is down 50% over last 12 months and is creating extreme pressure to perform, which management is turning into a toxic culture (note "management" not "leadership" as outside of the C-Suite, I see few real leaders in the organization)
-No fresh blood, all management is promoted from within, and existing management is recycled into different organizations to maintain "tribal knowledge" (results in "this is the way it's always been done")
-Lack of accountability throughout the organization
-Not a great strategy as industry evolves (no real 5G plan)
Advice to Management
Bring in leaders from other companies and other INDUSTRIES (everyone is a telco guy from way back).
Don't just acknowledge internal difficulties, accept responsibility. Upper management feels as much like opposition as AT&T, Verizon, or Zayo do, and there is no team camaraderie.
Culture matters and the "beatings will continue until morale improves" strategy will not help.

pros: Theres no pros at this place. Dont apply.
cons:
Theres too many to start. They hire 90% of their employees overseas. There is almost no training, so add both someone who knows no english and has no training and that's what you get every single time you call another department. The pay is absolutely horrible for what you have to put up. They cut your spliffs and your pay every month. You get yelled at all day for not being under 3 mins per call when you can't get assistance on helping someone. Imagine being at a job where you feel trapped; getting yelled at by your manager who doesnt know how to help you, while the customer is mad? Then multiply that by 8 hours. The pressure they put on you for sales is beyond humiliating. You get told you need to go home and tell your family you failed at your job because you forgot to offer a home phone to someone who told you how much they hate CenturyLink. There is no opportunity for advancement. They cut jobs sporadically so your job is never safe.
Advice to Management
Try calling on your day off and see how many reps transfer you and don't understand what you're saying. See how frustrating it is, then do something to fix it.
