employee_title: Senior Business Relationship Manager Inside Sales
review_title: Senior Business Relationship Manager inside Sales
pros: You will gain experience in handling disgruntled customers
cons:
You have to fight for much of your commission. Sales accounting is horrible.

There are no internal rules of customer engagement, so other sales reps inside CenturyLink are calling into your accounts offering cheaper products and undercutting your revenue. This affects your paycheck.

The company's marketing arm is out of control. Customers get spammed so much that your legitimate attempts to contact them get tuned out, making it harder to sell to your own account base. This affects your paycheck.

CenturyLink has been hoodwinked by an auto-dialing firm into turning their inside sales offices into call centers. You are forced into spending a portion of each day calling a set list of customers. The problem is the list is mostly the lower tier customers and loaded with bad data. Time would be much better spent calling real legitimate opportunities. This affects your paycheck.

Customer Care Managers, tasked with overseeing installations, are underpaid and overworked. They are also largely incompetent. The orders you place for your customers get ignored for weeks. CCMs don't return customer calls, either out of fear or lack of time. Mistakes are common. Orders get cancelled because timelines are not met. CenturyLink knows about this. They do nothing to fix it. This affects your paycheck.

Turnover in the company is out of control. They can't hire people fast enough. Training is largely non-existent. Morale is in the tank. There whole place is a dumpster fire burning out of control.
Advice to Management
Why offer advice? Management has devolved into one great debating society. Lots of talk. Nothing improves.
Helpful (2
advice_to_mgmt: Why offer advice? Management has devolved into one great debating society. Lots of talk. Nothing improves.

pros: This company used to be a great company to work for, the people were great and you enjoyed coming in everyday. You were left alone to do your job and you did it well because you felt proud of where you worked. UNTIL the last merger with Level 3.
cons:
The company has went down hill. Everyone either demoted or layoffs or put in jobs they hate. PTO, benefits, anything they can take away they are taking. Severance packages re-written to take money out of our pockets right before they know they are going to start laying off. They take and take until there is nothing left then find a reason to terminate you so they don't have to give you anything. They done this to too many employees already. Just waiting for the next shoe drop at every turn. Not a good place to work at all since the new CEO has taken over.
Advice to Management
Your employees run your company. They face YOUR customers. They ARE your customers. THEY can make your company GREAT. But you can't treat them like you do and throw them to the curb and expect a great return. You are ruining what used to be a Great company. Go back to the way it was before LEVEL 3!

review_title: Don’t have high expectations working here
pros: Work from home (only pro for working at this company)
cons:
- Zero chance of advancement or opportunity
- Zero raises in over (at least) 3years
- Expect to work hard and receive zero compensation
- High expectations but zero responsibily taken at the senior/political level: Expectations have raised but nothing has been done in over 6-12 months to help fix the same issues at hand.
- The problems and issues only continue to increase.
-The company will implement new systems causing multiple issues throughout the entire company and still expect the same revenue to be brought in. When it’s not, they fail to pay attention or listen to those working at the customer level about where the issues are or help provide solutions to fix them. 
- No workflow: majority of the company uses Outlook for the workflow system because due dates are so far behind they become irrelevant. 
- Expect to always have angry customers because the company cannot meet customer expectations or due dates listed within internal systems.
- Expect to chase teams/personnel to close past due tasks because they do not work off due dates. 
- Expect teams to hide behind DL Groups: when things go wrong, no one claims responsibility. 
- Expect to fix everyone else’s mistakes: internal teams do not take responsibility for their own errors and expect others to fix them.
Advice to Management
Actually implement processes that help those working at the customer level. There’s a lot of surveys and meetings being conducted with zero solutions being provided.

review_title: There is an inherent money issue with retaining talent.
pros: Work-Life Balance, FTO (No set PTO - take as many days as needed with approval), Bonuses.
cons:
HR reps to teams do a dog-&-pony show when asked about opening up budgets to retain talent. They know that they pay WELL below market value for all talent. The HR reps don't bat an eye when they lie to our face about it. They say 'non-direct payment (like bonuses and benefits) keep us at market level' with not even as much as a blush. It's robotic. It's embarrassing. 

CTL wants to be the network leader in services to small to large businesses, but will not open the wallet to retain talent. I've personally seen a team go from 15 people to 5 losing all tenured engineers and not give a raise to anyone that's keeping the team floating interested or around. They're systematically 'letting it go'. In 5 years there's been 1 raise and it was 3% - just enough to keep up with inflation for that year, even if you meet all your requirements of your job duties, even if you go WELL above and beyond because you know no one else will do it. 

Senior engineers get job offers from other competitors ranging from 115-130k which is equal to and above double what they pay our talent, and some management 100% goes to bat for them when faced with another person leaving, but falls short because finance/HR won't budge - or the counter-offer is 10% lower.

There is an inherent money issue with retaining talent - and this has unfortunate consequences. I've seen wonderful engineers move to different companies over and over again because they pay actual market value for talent. 

I'll see them soon myself.
Advice to Management
You're losing talent at an accelerated rate by 1. Hiring off-shore talent that we train and are incapable of network operations to keep costs down, 2. not promoting individuals, which generates a positive environment, 3. Adding senior level workloads to engineers who are still ideologically sound about working hard to get a raise - but it never comes.

The new CTL is all about team effort, but just below the kool-aid culture and value surface is a lot of people with resentment who know they're getting fleeced every year because you want to keep costs down. Maybe they'll start calling people to come back after it's too late? Maybe it'll be too late.
Helpful (2

review_title: Trying hard to make it work here
pros: Typically it is great because you represent one of the largest carriers and that in itself carries a lot of weight. Huge product and service portfolio to offer clients.
cons:
With the fact that they are so large the selling process is extremely process heavy, Sales Engineers and support staff are limited so it falls back on the seller. Keeping track of commissions is cumbersome.
Advice to Management
Stop running the reports, talk to the people and get a pulse on what the company needs rather than just acquiring and losing good talent. They will help you implement what you determine the company will do or be going forward but you need to listen.
